qas.question: What is the phenomenon where an organism looks like another species called?
Which organism looks like a bee but cannot sting?
A moth that has markings resembling an owl's eyes is an example of what phenomenon?
What is a defensive way that mimicry can be used?

answers.text: startling the predator and giving it time to escape

qas.question: What does a female firefly look like, but isn't able to sting?
What do drone flies copy to attract male fireflies?
What happens when drone flies attract male fireflies?
What do the markings on female fireflies resemble?
Why does a female firefly use the markings on its wings?

context: <a0_0><a2_0>Mimicry<a2_0/><a0_0/> is a related phenomenon where an organism has a similar appearance to another species. One such example is the <a1_0>drone fly<a1_0/>, which looks a lot like <b5_0>a bee<b5_0/>, yet is completely harmless as it cannot sting at all. Another example of batesian mimicry is the io moth, (Automeris io), which has markings on its wings that resemble <b8_0>an owl's eyes<b8_0/>. When an insectivorous predator disturbs the moth, it reveals its hind wings, temporarily <a3_0>startling the predator and giving it time <b9_0>to escape<b9_0/><a3_0/>. Predators may also use mimicry <a4_0>to lure their prey<a4_0/>, however. Female fireflies of the genus Photuris, for example, copy the <b6_0>light signals of other species<b6_0/>, thereby attracting male fireflies, which <b7_0>are then captured and eaten<b7_0/> (see aggressive mimicry).
